name.text: Interpreting Histograms and Frequency Polygons of Data

questiontext.text:
The histogram and frequency polygon below represent the time taken, \(t\) (in minutes), for a group of students to complete a Science experiment.

Use the graph to answer the questions below.

[[jsxgraph width="750px" height="450px"]] JXG.Options.text.useMathJax = true; // 1. IMPORT DATA FROM MAXIMA var x = [0, {#x1#}, {#x2#}, {#x3#}, {#x4#}, {#x5#}]; var h = [{#h1#}, {#h2#}, {#h3#}, {#h4#}, {#h5#}]; var max_h = Math.max(...h); var max_x = x[5]; // 2. INIT BOARD var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingBox: [-5, max_h + 2, max_x + 5, -2], grid: true, showNavigation: false, showCopyright: false, zoom: {enabled: false}, // Disable zoom pan: {enabled: false} // Disable panning }); // 3. AXES var yAxis = board.create("axis", [[0, 0], [0, max_h + 5]], { name: "\\(fd\\)", withLabel: true, label: { offset: [-20, 0] } }); var xAxis = board.create("axis", [[0, 0], [max_x + 5, 0]], { name: "\\(t\\,[min]\\)", withLabel: true, label: { offset: [-10, -20] } }); // 4. DRAW BARS (Histogram) var midPoints = []; for(let i=0; i<5; i++){ // Create Rectangles board.create('polygon', [ [x[i], 0], [x[i+1], 0], [x[i+1], h[i]], [x[i], h[i]] ], { fixed: true, // 1. Prevent dragging fillColor: '#004499', fillOpacity: 0.3, borders: { strokeColor: 'black', fixed: true // Lock borders }, vertices: { visible: false, // 2. Remove corner dots fixed: true // Lock vertices } }); // Store midpoints for Frequency Polygon midPoints.push([ (x[i]+x[i+1])/2, h[i] ]); } // 5. DRAW FREQUENCY POLYGON var p0 = board.create('point', [x[0], 0], {visible:false, fixed:true}); var pLast = board.create('point', [x[5], 0], {visible:false, fixed:true}); var points = []; for(let i=0; i

(a) What is the frequency density for the interval \({@x2@} < t \leq {@x3@}\)?

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

(b) Calculate the number of students (frequency) who took between \({@x1@}\) and \({@x2@}\) minutes.

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

(c) Calculate the total number of students who participated in the experiment.

[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

(d) Estimate the number of students who took less than {@T_cut@} minutes.

[[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

(a) Reading Frequency Density

To find the frequency density, we look at the height of the bar on the vertical axis.

For the interval \({@x2@} < t \leq {@x3@}\), the height of the corresponding bar is {@h3@}.

Therefore, the frequency density is {@ta1@}.

(b) Calculating Frequency

In a histogram, the area of the bar represents the frequency. The formula is:

\( \text{Frequency} = \text{Width} \times \text{Frequency Density} \)

We are asked for the frequency of the interval \({@x1@} < t \leq {@x2@}\).

  • Class Width: The interval is from {@x1@} to {@x2@}, so the width is \( {@x2@} - {@x1@} = {@w2@} \).
  • Frequency Density: From the graph, the height of this bar is {@h2@}.
  • Calculation: \( {@w2@} \times {@h2@} = \mathbf{@ta2@} \).

(c) Total Frequency

To find the total number of students, we calculate the area of every bar in the histogram and add them together.

Interval Width Height (FD) Frequency (Area)
\(0 < t \leq {@x1@}\) {@w1@} {@h1@} \( {@w1@} \times {@h1@} = {@freq1@} \)
\({@x1@} < t \leq {@x2@}\) {@w2@} {@h2@} \( {@w2@} \times {@h2@} = {@freq2@} \)
\({@x2@} < t \leq {@x3@}\) {@w3@} {@h3@} \( {@w3@} \times {@h3@} = {@freq3@} \)
\({@x3@} < t \leq {@x4@}\) {@w4@} {@h4@} \( {@w4@} \times {@h4@} = {@freq4@} \)
\({@x4@} < t \leq {@x5@}\) {@w5@} {@h5@} \( {@w5@} \times {@h5@} = {@freq5@} \)
Total: {@ta3@}

(d) Estimation

We need to estimate the number of students who took less than {@T_cut@} minutes.

This time \({@T_cut@}\) falls inside the interval \({@x3@} < t \leq {@x4@}\). We split our calculation into two parts:

  1. Full Intervals: All students in the intervals before {@x3@} minutes are included.
    Sum = \({@freq1@} + {@freq2@} + {@freq3@} = {@sum_prev@}\).
  2. Partial Interval: We need the students between {@x3@} and {@T_cut@}.
    • The width of this partial section is \( {@T_cut@} - {@x3@} = {@p_width@} \).
    • The height (frequency density) of this bar is {@h4@}.
    • Partial Frequency = \( {@p_width@} \times {@h4@} = {@freq_partial@} \).

Total Estimate: \( {@sum_prev@} + {@freq_partial@} = \mathbf{@ta4@} \).

questiondescription.text:
Daniel Murunga

Given a histogram and frequency polygon representing the time taken by students to complete a Science experiment, the student is required to interpret the graph to determine frequency densities, calculate interval frequencies, determine the total number of students, and estimate the frequency below a specific time.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: node_test : if ta1=ans1 and ans2=ta2 and ans3=ta3 and ans4=ta4 then 1 else 0;

node.description: checks for the correct answer to all the inputs

truefeedback.text: Correct answer, well done. You accurately identified the frequency density by reading the height of the bar for the interval \({@x2@} < t \leq {@x3@}\) from the vertical axis.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. Check the vertical axis (\(y\)-axis) again. The frequency density corresponds exactly to the height of the rectangular bar for the interval \({@x2@} < t \leq {@x3@}\).

truefeedback.text: Correct answer, well done. You correctly calculated the frequency (number of students) by finding the area of the bar: \(\text{Frequency} = \text{Width} \times \text{Height}\).

falsefeedback.text:
Incorrect answer. Remember that in a histogram, the frequency is represented by the area of the bar.
Multiply the width of the interval \({@x1@} < t \leq {@x2@}\) by its frequency density (height).

truefeedback.text: Correct answer, well done. You correctly found the total number of students by calculating the area of every bar in the histogram and summing them up.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect answer. To find the total number of students, you must calculate the frequency (area) for all 5 bars individually and then add those totals together.

truefeedback.text: Correct answer, well done. You correctly estimated the value by summing the full bars to the left and calculating the partial area for the interval containing {@T_cut@} minutes.

falsefeedback.text:
Incorrect answer. To estimate the count for less than {@T_cut@} minutes:
1. Sum the frequencies of all intervals that are completely below {@T_cut@}.
2. Calculate the area of the partial section of the specific bar where {@T_cut@} falls (use the new partial width \(\times\) height).
3. Add these together.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
